article.description: Jawad Williams and Sean May each scored 17 points and North Carolina gave Virginia Tech a rough welcome to Atlantic Coast Conference basketball, beating the Hokies 85-51.
article.headline: Williams, May help UNC win 8th straight game
article.linkText: Tar Heels spank Hokies to win ACC opener
article.story: BLACKSBURG, Va. (AP) -- "Welcome to the ACC." North Carolina's Sean May spoke those words to Virginia Tech's Deron Washington after dunking in his face, and the Tar Heels (No. 6 ESPN/USA Today, No. 5 AP) delivered the message throughout the Hokies' first game in the Atlantic Coast Conference. "I told him, 'Hey, welcome to the ACC, baby,'" May said of Washington after he and Jawad Williams each scored 17 points and Raymond Felton had 15 in North Carolina's 85-51 victory Sunday, its eighth straight. The Tar Heels (8-1) started slowly, turning the ball over 12 times in the first half, but used a 17-4 run to take a 41-27 halftime lead. A 16-5 burst to begin the second half ended the suspense and highlighted how well the Tar Heels can play when they exploit opponents inside. Williams finished 7-for-8 from the field, May was 6-for-8 and freshman Marvin Williams was 5-for-6 and scored 12 points. "After the first six or seven minutes, we did a great job offensively," Tar Heels coach Roy Williams said before signing autographs outside the team's locker room. "We were able to get the ball inside." Virginia Tech (5-3), overmatched inside and out, kept it close for the first 15 minutes on the strength of Zabian Dowdell's 16-point first half but couldn't keep pace once the Tar Heels starting looking underneath. It was a rough way to be indoctrinated into the conference, Dowdell said, and a welcome that will drive the Hokies to get tougher and better in a league that has seven teams ranked in the Top 25, four in the first seven. "There's no time to be getting discouraged," Dowdell said. "We just have to continue to work hard. We can say we know how good teams in the ACC can be right about now. We just have to think about this game when we're in practice. When you get tired, you've just got to go harder." Dowdell led the Hokies with 21 points and Carlos Dixon and Jamon Gordon each had nine. The Hokies shot 36 percent to North Carolina's 65 percent, were outrebounded 34-24 and outscored down low 48-26. But the early going was encouraging, Dixon said. "We handled their transition, we got back on defense and we limited them to one shot," he said. After the Tar Heels' run, "we got mentally and physically drained. ... We saw a lot of things that we need to work on." North Carolina emptied the bench in the second half, using 14 players. The Tar Heels led 71-41 after two free throws by May with 6:20 to play, and the rest of the game was essentially a demonstration of individual skills as players for both teams attempted highlight reel dunks and passes. The Tar Heels scored the game's last 10 points. Dowdell's third 3-pointer of the first half pulled the Hokies within 24-23, and then North Carolina got serious, exploiting the Hokies inside. May had 11 points in the half and Jawad Williams nine.
